module_component:
- Data Workbench, Asset Management, Incident Management - monoliths (aroound 2k lines of code in single file )
- many components that have around 800 lines other than the monoliths mentioned above
finding: - data fetching, filtering, sorting, metrics calculation, export/import, multiple views, dialogs with all those state variables also defined in the same file
impact: Testability (mocking whole component), Maintainability (multiple error surface areas and re-renders), Reusability etc becomes really difficult
solution: - break down monolith into components like DataWorkbenchHeader, DataWorkbenchMetrics with respective hooks like useDataWorkbenchFilters, useDataWorkbenchMetrics for centralized component wise access
notes:
- We should not have big monolithic components which are difficult to maintain and/or scale
- inconsistent implement with partial component implementation with different tabs (FuelTab, Maintenance Tab etc)
- we can have component level eslint rule set for size of file

finding: All logic in one class the same component defines UI elements list , data grids, forms (add/edit)
impact: similar to above
solution:
- break down the file into child components or use reusable components like data list, basic form and write data providers to populate respective data lists and forms specific to the UI
- implement component specific hook for better maintainability

finding:
- The current structure has flat folder sttucture. 
- 50+ files in single directory
impact: no logical grouping or feature boundaries or code ownership
solution:
adopt feature based structure : src/components/modules/
├── fleet/                       # Fleet management features
│   ├── FleetDashboard/
│   ├── VehicleTelemetry/
│   ├── GPSTracking/
│   └── VirtualGarage/
├── maintenance/                 # Maintenance features
│   ├── MaintenanceScheduling/
│   ├── MaintenanceRequest/
│   ├── GarageService/
│   └── PredictiveMaintenance/

module_component: Data Workbenc, FleetDashboard, AssetManagement and many more
impact:
1) if generic filters logic changes we have so many touch points and our maintanence costs increase by n folds based on same logic copied over for all filteration login in most compoenents

2) if we run duplication checks in our code i think we might have atleast 20-25% code duplication cases
solution:
- create useVehicleFilters hook
- create useFleetMetrics hook 
- create utulity hooks/functions for these common logics
- single place for changes decreasing the total surface area for errors

finding:
only 3 enabled option: 
"strictNullChecks": true,              
  "noFallthroughCasesInSwitch": true,
  "noUncheckedSideEffectImports": true
impact: - things like using any keyword are banned by most of the IT companies for function parameters, state variables , api responses
solution:
- we can add the following options too :
"strict": true,                        // ❌ Enables all strict options at once
  "noImplicitAny": true,                 // ❌ Disallows implicit 'any' types
  "strictFunctionTypes": true,           // ❌ Stricter function type checking
  "strictBindCallApply": true,           // ❌ Type checking for bind/call/apply
  "strictPropertyInitialization": true,  // ❌ Class properties must be initialized
  "noImplicitThis": true,                // ❌ Disallows implicit 'any' for 'this'
  "alwaysStrict": true,                  // ❌ Emit "use strict" in output
- find out where we have this keyword used and check for impact and replace

finding: not configured at all

- No enforcement of TypeScript rules

- No detection of unused code

key_metric: Session data and toen data  in local storage
finding: -incorrect confirguration
impact:
- Client-Side Sessions**: Sessions should be server-side (Redis/database)
-Sensitive Data Exposed**: userId, tenantId, role, permissions in localStorage
- API Tokens in localStorage**: Long-lived tokens exposed to XSS
-No Hashing**: Tokens stored in plain text
- No Encryption**: Anyone with XSS can steal API tokens

key_metric: - Excessive useState with No useReducer Adoption
finding: - files like DataWorkbench.tsx  have 15+ separate useState calls
impact:
- highly succeptible to throwing run time errors that will be difficult to debug 
- Complex setState calls with multiple dependencies
solution:
- for complex compoennets and state logic we should use useReducer to manage multiple state values

finding: - we have like 120 + instances where we are using usememo, usecallback
impact: -ever growing boiler plate code that can be eliminated with just one library usage
solution:
Use react compiler to Automatically memoizes components and values: 
- Enforces Rules of Hooks at compile time
- Eliminates need for manual `useMemo`, `useCallback`, `React.memo`
- Reduces boilerplate by 30-40%
- Prevents common performance pitfalls

impact: nan

finding:
- need to modif two properties
- "strict": true, "noEmitOnError": true,
impact:
- Disables all strict type checking
   - No null/undefined checks
   - No implicit any checks
   - No strict function types
- Compiles even with errors
   - Allows broken code to be deployed
solution:
- "compilerOptions": {
    "strict": true,                    // Enable all strict checks
    "noEmitOnError": true,             // Don't compile with errors
    "noUnusedLocals": true,            // Catch unused variables
    "noUnusedParameters": true,        // Catch unused parameters
    "noImplicitReturns": true,         // Ensure all code paths return
    "noFallthroughCasesInSwitch": true // Catch switch fallthrough
  }

impact:
- need to implement error hierarchy with app level errors
- Update Routes to Use Custom Errors

Error (built-in)
   └── AppError (base custom error)
       ├── ValidationError (400)
       ├── UnauthorizedError (401)
       ├── Forbidden Error (403)
       ├── NotFoundError (404)
       ├── ConflictError (409)
       └── InternalError (500)

- return res.status(500).json({
    error: 'Internal Server Error',
    code: 'INTERNAL_ERROR',
    ...(process.env.NODE_ENV === 'development' && {
      message: err.message,
      stack: err.stack
    })
  })

finding: - Multiple routes fetch related data in loops
solution:
**Remediation**: Use JOINs or batch queries
   ```typescript
   // ✅ GOOD: Single query with JOINs
   const result = await pool.query(`
     SELECT 
       c.*,
       json_agg(DISTINCT jsonb_build_object(
         'entity_type', cel.entity_type,
         'entity_id', cel.entity_id,
         'link_type', cel.link_type
       )) FILTER (WHERE cel.id IS NOT NULL) as linked_entities,
       json_agg(DISTINCT jsonb_build_object(
         'id', ca.id,
         'filename', ca.filename,
         'url', ca.url
       )) FILTER (WHERE ca.id IS NOT NULL) as attachments
     FROM communications c
     LEFT JOIN communication_entity_links cel ON c.id = cel.communication_id
     LEFT JOIN communication_attachments ca ON c.id = ca.communication_id
     WHERE c.id = $1 AND c.tenant_id = $2
     GROUP BY c.id
   `, [req.params.id, req.user!.tenant_id])

finding: - no measure on which api's are slow and need to be looked into
impact: -Can't identify slow endpoints
solution: - we can add response time middleware in the start before we have a hold on every api performance matching our benchmark

impact: - the initial dev part should have memory leak tool to identify to identify leaks

key_metric: Worker Threads for CPU intensive tasks
finding: - not using worker threads at all
impact:
-  All requests blocked during generation/processing
-  event loop gets choked
solution:
- we can identify places to use worker thread ,s pecially where there are : 
- CPU-intensive computations (image processing, encryption) - external AI and other tool calls (if needed)
- Heavy JSON parsing/serialization
- Data transformation (large datasets)
- Cryptographic operations

finding: - have to identify hot spots for this as i didnt find usage of streams in the code
impact: - app memory gets loaded with unnecessary information slowing everything else
solution:
- use streams when loading big file in memory . we don't need to load the whole 50 mb file in memory
- use for things like csv or excel export , rather than getting all the data loaded into memory to dump to an csv , collect and push 100 records at a time and similar
